item.title: India Ink: How Surveillance Works in India
item.description: There is a strange mix of great amounts of transparency and very little accountability when it comes to surveillance and intelligence agencies.
item.dc:creator: By PRANESH PRAKASH
item.media:description: Demonstrators showing support for National Security Agency whistleblower Edward Snowden at India Gate in New Delhi on Sunday.

item.title: South Korean Managers Return to Shuttered Plant in North
item.description: The arrival of 60 factory managers was another sign of a thaw in relations between North and South Korea after several months of tensions between the two.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Masao Yoshida, Nuclear Engineer and Chief at Fukushima Plant, Dies at 58
item.description: Mr. Yoshida won praise for his effort to minimize the damage at the power plant as multiple reactors spiraled out of control after a tsunami.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Prime Minister's Office of Japan, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Japan's Prime Minister, Yoshihiko Noda, center, listens to Masao Yoshida, left, at the crippled Fukushima nuclear power plant in September 2011.

item.title: Egypt Leaders’ Transition Plan Meets With Swift Criticism
item.description: Egypt’s new military-led government enlisted internationally recognized figures to serve as its public face and promised quick elections, but a transitional plan was widely derided as authoritarian and rushed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Supporters of deposed President Mohamed Morsi camped out in Rabaa Adawiya square on Tuesday.

item.title: Inquiry Suggests Chance That Mechanical Failure Had Role in Crash
item.description: The pilots of the Asiana Airlines jet said that they believed they had set devices used to maintain safe airspeed but that speed fell too low anyway, an investigation revealed.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: Deborah A. P. Hersman said the National Transportation Safety Board requested data from Federal Aviation Administration.

item.title: Austin Goodrich, Spy Who Posed as Journalist, Dies at 87
item.description: In the 1950s and ’60s, numerous secret agents for the United States used journalism as a cover. Mr. Goodrich, unlike some, considered himself primarily a spy.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: Austin Goodrich reporting in Stockholm in 1951.

item.title: Interim Premier in Egypt Could Cut Subsidies
item.description: Hazem el-Beblawi’s selection as interim prime minister appeared to signal that the military-led transitional government would proceed with economic reforms.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Egypt Is Arena for Influence of Arab Rivals
item.description: Two of the Persian Gulf’s richest monarchies pledged $8 billion in cash and loans to Egypt, aiming to shore up a shaky government and undermine their rivals.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:description: The interim Egyptian president, Adli Mansour, center, met with officials of the United Arab Emirates in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: Currency Controls in Cyprus Increase Worry About Euro System
item.description: Though part of the euro zone, the country’s restrictions on the flow of capital have affected businesses and individuals, leaving some feeling their euro is not the same as that of others.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marios Loucaides, a Cypriot entrepreneur, had a deal collapse after he was prevented from moving euros to Greece.

item.title: Extradited Colombian to Face Charges of Drug Trafficking
item.description: Daniel Barrera, who was also known as El Loco, was extradited on charges that he manufactured large quantities of cocaine and trafficked it to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Parliament Asks Murdoch to Discuss Hacking
item.description: The British Parliament called on Rupert Murdoch to discuss recorded comments he made to journalists and newspaper executives in March about the culture of paying off police.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUGHNEY

item.title: World Briefing | the Americas: Canada: Criminal Investigation Is Begun Into Deadly Train Crash
item.description: The authorities have opened a criminal investigation into the fiery wreck of a runaway oil train on Saturday in Lac-Megantic, Quebec.
item.dc:creator: By ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Portugal, a Protector of a People Is Honored
item.description: Descendants of those saved from Nazism by Aristides de Sousa Mendes gathered to pay tribute to the former diplomat.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Joao Pedro Marnoto for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: The abandoned home of Aristides de Sousa Mendes, a Portuguese diplomat who helped thousands escape Nazi persecution, was the site of a tribute last month.

item.title: The Lede: New Video Appears to Show How Predawn Raid Unfolded in Cairo
item.description: Twenty-eight minutes of video emerge, recorded by a witness to Monday’s deadly clashes in Cairo, that appear to offer the first clear images of the predawn phase of the confrontation.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Scandal in Bohemia
item.description: Bribes and the misuse of power? For Czechs, it could be worse.
item.dc:creator: By DEREK SAYER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia and Herzegovina: More Srebrenica Victims Are Identified
item.description: Mourners lined the streets of Sarajevo on Tuesday as trucks carried the remains of 409 newly identified victims of the Srebrenica massacre to their final resting place.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Foreign Worker Abducted
item.description: A Lebanese manager of a construction company was kidnapped by gunmen during an attack in which three soldiers were wounded.
item.category: Ansaru (Vanguard for the Protection of Muslims in Black Africa)
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Havana Journal: Salons or Not, Cyberspace Is Still a Distant Place for Most Cubans
item.description: Regarded as the least wired country in the Western Hemisphere, Cuba recently expanded access in salons. But the prices are beyond what most can afford.
item.category: Empresa de Telecomunicaciones de Cuba SA (Etecsa)
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Jose Goitia for The New York Times
item.media:description: Web surfers at a Nauta cybersalon in Havana last week. Many Cubans have never been online.

item.title: New Prayer Confrontation at Western Wall
item.description: Two ultra-Orthodox men were arrested on suspicion of throwing objects at the women in an activist group, in the latest clash at one of Judaism’s holiest sites.
item.dc:creator: By ALYZA SEBENIUS and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A member of the Women of the Wall organization, which recently won a court decision protecting women’s right to wear religious garments traditionally used by men, prayed while wearing a prayer shawl outside the Western Wall on Monday.

item.title: Russia Says Study Suggests Syria Rebels Used Sarin
item.description: The Russian analysis was based on evidence collected directly by Russian forensics specialists who visited a site in northern Syria, an official said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: As one member of the Free Syrian Army took his position inside the Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo on Monday to fight forces loyal to the embattled president, Bashar al-Assad, another rebel, at left, took a moment to snap a photograph with his cellphone.

item.title: Europe Has Plan for Failed Banks, but Germany Isn’t Convinced
item.description: Germany’s finance minister said a proposal for new policies and a central authority to handle failed banks risked making economic problems worse.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: For Western Allies, a Long History of Swapping Intelligence
item.description: Recent disclosures of American spying reflect the complicated nature of the relationship between the intelligence services of the United States and its allies.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Car Bombing Injures Dozens in Hezbollah Section of Beirut
item.description: The bombing came amid longstanding fears that Hezbollah would face attacks in response to its military intervention in Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A firefighter tried to extinguish fires from an explosion in Beirut's Bir al-Abed neighborhood on Tuesday.

item.title: Latest Twist at Bolshoi: Director Is Pushed Out
item.description: After six months of scandals at the Bolshoi, including the acid attack on the ballet’s artistic director, the Ministry of Culture has abruptly fired the general director, Anatoly Iksanov.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:credit: Damir Yusupov/Bolshoi Theater, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The newly appointed director general of the Bolshoi Theater Vladimir Urin, left, and the former director general Anatoly Iksanov, at a news conference on Tuesday in Moscow.

item.title: Journalist Assassinated in Violent Russian Republic
item.description: The journalist, Akhmednabi Akhmednabiyev, had accused local authorities of persecuting and kidnapping Muslims and was shot to death while driving his car.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
